title: Sinister Clowns in the Shroud of Turin Burn Marks
post: Colin Berry does not say that scorch marks are not detectable over a long period of time. That would truly be absurd. He has said that the shroud image looks very like a scorch, which indeed it does, and has conducted a number of experiments which demonstrate this. The problem is that scorch marks also fluoresce quite brightly under ultra-violet light, and we are told that the shroud image does not. Experiments I am carrying out, albeit so far unsuccessfully, are attempting to produce visible scorches that do not fluoresce. If these experiments are consistently unsuccessful, the claim that the image might be a scorch is weakened, although time may be a factor which I do not have long enough (700 years or so) really to explore.
author: Hugh Farey
